data.content: Mahou Shoujo 201 is heavily influenced by Machikado Mazoku, just with a lot more ecchi. Both Shamiko and Fujiyama are presented as inept "villains" who are poor due to the involvement of magical girls and they need to defeat a magical girl to alleviate their current situation (Fujiyama's poverty, Shamiko's family seal). They both have very similar personalities. Momo and Mamu are insanely overpowered and rely mostly on brute force instead of magic. They also have very similar personalities. Momo and Mamu move in next door to Shamiko and Fujiyama. It's all just too on the nose to be a coincidence.

Yumemiru Maid no Tea Time is an overtly yuri version of Gochuumon wa Usagi desu ka?. Both series are about girls working in a café and their daily interactions as well as their interactions with the girls working in a rival café. Ranko is very obviously modeled after Syaro, they're not even trying to hide it. The café that they work at in Yumemiru is called Bloom, likely a reference to the final season of the GochiUsa animé of the same name. GochiUsa has a much slower and more engaging plot.
poor kid meets a weird chick changed his life but ends up considerably worse
Two weird / lowkey immortal girls and their movie binging sessions

Instead of high school teams, both protagonists are based in out-of-school clubs for their particular sport. Both manga also have great side characters and excellent character development for the MC! These two are definitely my favourite sports animanga :D

The Plot of the story used in both manhwa is the world in the novel with the main character taking on the role of an Extra character in the novel. the difference is that in omniscient Reader manhwa, MC's world turns into a part of the novel he is reading. on the other hand, the MC in the novel's Extra is sent to a different world in the novel he is reading.

Lesbian schoolgirls with superpowers

- Epic world-building: every detail feels very intentional, so the worlds in both stories feel complete and immersive with very minimal loose ends. Not only that, both stories compel you to deep dive and question the worlds too just like the protagonists. They're very meta and genre-bending, characteristic of their same author. - Foreshadowing: in so many cases, information that seems insignificant will complement new reveals that happen later on in the story. It really adds to the in-depthness of the world-building. The stories definitely have reread value. - Characters: despite the extremely fantastical settings, the characters' intentions are properly justifiable throughout the story (more so Omniscient Reader). It makes the world that much more immersive.

entry.title: Itai no wa Iya nanode Bougyoryoku ni Kyokufuri Shitai to Omoimasu.
Sekai Saikyou no Majo, Hajimemashita: Watashi dake "Kouryaku Site" wo Mireru Sekai de Jiyuu ni Ikimasu

data.content: Both series have protagonists that are similar to each other in personality, responses to their surroundings, and increasing development of their abilities. These character traits make them fun to watch over when reading the story. Both stories also are peppered with entertaining side characters and shout-out references to other series.

Shimeji Simulation and Game-bu are both comfortable mangas. Both have a nice touch of coziness and happiness in everyday life to them while also have different sides to them. Both art styles are very fun. Both feature a diverse line of characters.

entry.title: Tonari no Furi-san ga Tonikaku Kowai.

data.content: Both are based on a same fundamental idea: a romance between a scary lookig/seaming girl and her classmate, tho Furi-san is a bit more melow and has more comedic moments.

Ao Ashi is quite similar to Diamond no Ace, but it takes a deeper dive into tactics and the mental states of players. It also explores the differences and rivalries between youth schools and regular schools in more detail. Overall, while Diamond no Ace has a slice-of-life element in the sense that it doesn't focus solely on intense action-packed competition all the time like Haikyuu or Ao Ashi, Ao Ashi will offers an even more technical perspective on the sport and the league environment. While I'm recommending Ao Ashi, Oshi no Ko is another good choice. It's essentially the same as Ao Ashi but delves deeply into the entertainment industry instead, with added drama, mystery, and romance.
Both give the similar "dark vibe", if you know what I mean. Dark, psychological stories that really make you think about life.

LGBT-themed one-shots by the same author about a couple who find themselves incompatible because of their sexuality (Mine being asexual in Mine-kun wa Non-Sexual) or gender identity (They being a trans man or genderfluid in Silkscreen).
They both are nice stories in the, what I now call, "What matters? Good food!" genre.
Both are fantasy adventure story where cooking plays an important part in nearly every chapter
Both protagonists are high school trans boys who are initially closeted because they don't want to stand out but learn to accept themselves for who they are.

Their focus on a group of characters embarking on a grand adventure. In both series, the main characters travel to different places, meet new people, and face various challenges along the way, both series explore themes of friendship, loyalty, and personal growth as the characters overcome obstacles and work together to achieve their goals

Both manga are about a mind reading protagonist who reads the mind of someone who likes them (in Kijima-san, the guy is the mind reader; in Takamori-kun, the girl is the mind reader). Both manga are very wholesome and adorable and have the same vibe. If you liked one of them and want more, then the other is a great place to start.
- Same Author. - Both have wholesome MCs. - Fight scenes are structured similarly.
Both series take place in an Imperial Court that stars a female lead who is trying to take care of a male lead who happens to be cursed.
Similar premise about a country girl, moving to a new town, in a new environment. The story involves the main characters to deal with their differences and understand each other feelings.

Episodic plot structure. In both mangas, guests (spoiler: which are dead) rest in a lodging establishment (hotel or inn) where they can figure out what's holding them back from moving on. Each story dives into different aspects of life, death and loss in a very beautiful and lyrical way. Also, one of the main characters is a reserved black-haired guy wearing glasses.
Supernatural coming of age stories that really capture that feeling of eternal, joyful youth and the ups and downs that come with it.

Realistic depictions of martial arts. Holyland focusing on street fighting and Meguru on MMA. Both have extremely similar vibes.

Both have fantasy settings and have strong world building and magic systems in place. They have similar heartwarming stories and character development. Reading both mangas kinda feel like getting a warm hug :'))
20th century boys and punpun both have a similar seinen coming of age feel, while intriguing you with the depth of the characters
Violent criminal underworld, realistic down to earth fights where the most wicked wins. Both are somewhat gory and have a sense of justice faded in the background but still lingering.

very close vibe, similar characters, both follow a group of very people from all over the world with mysterious and diverse backgrounds fighting in the underworld and the two manga have a similar depiction of fights

Centuria and Sensou Kyoushitsu (The Bugle Call) have an art style and worldbuilding more in common with history inspired manga like vinland saga than what you would expect of a medieval fantasy setting. Similar themes of violence, life purpose and freedom.

They are a little atypical isekai-romace-manhwa with lots of humor & very coherent storytelling BUT also a bunch of plot-tiwsts - breaking the 4th wall from time to time. ;-) Just fun to (binge) read having a similar vibe!
if you like stories that handle darker subjects with grace & proper emotional weight to their subject matter, monster is actually undefeated no exaggeration

The everyday life of a shopkeeper running a shop in the middle of nowhere and the bonds she forms with the people she interacts with. Both titles are heavy on fantasy and are very slice-of-life with mono no aware themes (much stronger in Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou, the pinnacle of mono no aware).

A highly energetic girl with extreme strength that goes around and often times causes havoc or misery to others. A vast cast of utterly ridiculous characters that have very little to no normal traits, often times they will be complete scumbags or at least morally ambiguous too Casual/Non-stimulating sexual humor in almost every chapter.
Cute girls do cute things in a world void of life and filled with monsters. Somewhat similar characters, not the same setting, but the characters do find themselves in similar situations.

Both series have a very similar premise: A girls' classmate dies before the story starts, and has come back as a ghost. While having the potential of a supernatural romance seems lovely, there is something sinister beneath the surface involving both ghosts. There is something mysterious going on with mysterious rituals, other ghosts, and the true nature of Aizawa and Aono. Both series have a lot of mystery, horror, and romance elements, and I like how they both take similar concepts and ideas and twist them in different ways. Mietamasu yo! Aizawa-san is not simply the yuri version of I Want to Hold Aono-kun So Badly I Could Die. Aono-kun has the couple get together quickly, while Aizawa-san is a lot more of a slow burn. They both introduce the horror and mystery of the world in different ways, with Aono seeming a bit more forward with triggering topics and Aizawa-san introducing the more overt horror and mystery elements more gradually. Aizawa-san also begins with a more comedic tone, particularly in the earliest chapters.
Similar themes of novel characters facing the reality of their existence and the meaning of fiction in this context. I know this sounds vague but going into detail would be a spoiler for both series.
Both are some of the saddest manga I've ever read. The atmosphere is the same, completely depressing, but there is always hope.
These mangas are about two very intelligent protagonists who like to play mindgames.
Both stories are about a love story between a human and a supernatural being. These relationships are very complicated and the protagonists have to overcome many obstacles to get together.
If you liked I''s and want to take the next step into painful romance, go ahead and read Kimi no Iru Machi
revenge theme against 5 ppl but good

Both are wacky adventure series that seems childish at first but becomes dark tho toriko is more optimistic cook is basically a hunter with how the world revolves around them boith have a dark continent arc taht throws their entire power scaling out of wack

Theyre literally the same kind of battle shounen > appeals to woman(yes despite all the horny bait ft has a sizeable female fanbase) >hot dudes > every arc is just introducing a new villain group for the main cast to 1 v 1 > every arc they try to bait deaths for tensions but everyone always survives > alot of spinoffs for the other char tho in bungou case its prequel LNs > akira ishida is voicing the final villain of both series and theyre both immortal op emo edgelords
Both have Idol culture in them Both have mystery and drama Both dive deep in characters who work with idols and media

The first part of the plot, in terms of anime, till season 1, is a carbon copy of the plot. It is arguably one of the best reverse isekai manga out there. The story is the same: a dragon from another world comes to this world injured and, by chance of fate, meets an overworked drunk office worker who rescues her, and as a token of appreciation, the dragon decides to work at her house as a maid. It is a downright amazing storyline, and it is a calm and steady slice-of-life storyline with some freakishly good fighting scenes, making it an all-around good manga to recommend. However, the quality of the storyline has degraded severely since the second season of the anime of the same name, but it still deserves a read and watch.
Both protagonists use unconventional skills, like farming, cooking and crafting to win in their monster ruled worlds of a dungeon. Plus both have bunnys companions!

Both are uncannily similar. They both start with, essentially, blackmail, but never take the hard turn that you would expect from a title about blackmail. So both series, miraculously, stay light and fluffy. The blackmailer in both have identical reasons for doing what they are doing and the one being blackmailed in both only put up mild resistance and quickly start to question if they actually have feelings for the blackmailer. Both series also feature a side story of unrequited love and regret. Where they differ is Ichido is R rated while Lonely Girl is very PG. That being said the blackmail is actually heavier in Lonely Girl than in Ichido as the blackmailer in Ichido feels remorse for her actions and eases off while the blackmailer in Lonely Girl is happy to be close to the girl being blackmailed and leans into it.

data.content: Both protagonists are quirky characters acting as villainesses to achieve the best ending with a capable butler who is their confidante, right hand and love interest. However, they end up failing due to others being able to perceive their innate kindness. The mangas both have humour and interesting dynamics between the lead characters.

Both are gritty, dark, and follow a protagonist who seriously just can't catch a break. If you love the art style of Berserk, particularly in the Golden Age arc, you may also love Innocent's style. Gorey, tragic, and deeply interesting character studies.
Volleyball themed manga where the main character is short. Chiisai Boku is fairly new and story-wise is more focused on the romance aspect. If you like volleyball manga then you can check them out.

Both works are demonstrative of psychological character study and grapple with profound existentialist themes. They are coming-of-age stories in which the protagonist - and their understanding of themselves and the world around them - dramatically evolves alongside the plot.

Similar characters, FL is cold calm and collected (majority of the time). ML is very in love with FL and her biggest fan. There is a funny best friend who can be a bit overbearing at times but overall is a good character. Well rounded characters in general, ML is cute and pretty, like most FL in romances, and in contrast FL is kind of masculine and elegant.

Revenge manga in which the main character uses a disguise or alter ego to get back at the unfairness of their past, using violence as needed, and swaying public opinion into their advantage.

entry.title: Boku ga Shinu dake no Hyakumonogatari

data.content: Both of these manga are episodic horrors, each chapters is more or less a standalone story about in universe urban legends and unusual supernatural tales. Over the course of the series, each manga has slight lore building where these episodic tales slightly tie together. the only difference is in boku ga, these stories overarch in the opening pages and are seen from the narrators POV. While in Zangekikan the stories themselves are very loosely related and revealed to be in a shared universe of sorts

These manga are so similar that after a year or so long break from not reading them, I came back to pick one up and realized I had started the wrong manga. This is not a joke. From the edgy revenge plot, sexy side characters that like the MC for zero reason all the way to the dungeon heavy premise. These stories might as well be the same thing
Both of these manga focus on highly skilled assassins that feel remorse for their work, though this remorse is for different reasons.
Both of these manga focus on delinquents and fighting, their entire premise can be summed up by "yankees killing each other"
Both of these series are about an assassin with absurdly high skill levels

These manga are about semi-retired hitmen, both of which are considered the best of the best, on top of this both manga lean very heavy into their comedy tags and love to make fun of the fact that the main character is a serial murder machine with a very unusual and unexpected day job
Both of these manga focus heavily on reluctant assassins that are considered the best in their country/etc
Both of these manga focus heavily on absurd assassination plotlines that go beyond the means of regular human beings, the action is almost constant and both manga lean very heavily into their comedy.
Both of these manga are episodic in nature and focus on telling more urban legend type of horror stories that are supposed to be mystical and supernatural in nature.

Both of these manga focus on extremely melodramatic personal dramas that are full of angst, edge, sex and other equally shallow and pointless themes all in an effort to be deep and thought provoking in some way shape or form
Both of these manga focus on a school age cast, and their lives in a post apocalyptic survival setting. If you enjoyed the school arc most in high school of the dead, this manga will more your speed.
Both of these manga are post apocalyptic survival dramas that focus on the undead/zombies.

Both of these manga are pure, unbridled smut pieces written into the most gory, chaotic zombie apocalypse settings ever. If your favorite part of high school of the dead was the big boobies and girls this is the manga for you my friend

entry.title: Conveni of the Dead: 100-nichigo ni Kyuujo sareru Conveni Tenin

data.content: If you liked the more laid back, slice of life zombie survival aspects of high school of dead you will like conveni of the dead. The arcs where they spend their time prepping and barricading themselves into safe houses is basically the entirety of conveni of the dead.
Both of these manga focus on zombie centric stories with young adult casts, both are semi fan servicey
These are both stories that focus on high school aged students trying their best survive the zombie apocalypse, mostly in a school setting, until they venture outside of their comfort zones.

Pumpkin Scissors is in a diesel-punk world modeled after early 20th century Europe where human experimentation is one of the major themes. Pumpkins Scissors has a more comedic edge than AoT, but they have similar settings and both have extremely brutal combat segments. Both MCs have to change into monsters when they fight; but for our main character Randell, he's more of a metaphorical monster that becomes an unfeeling killing machine, while Erin Jeager literally turns into a monster.

Both are Chinese BL novels revolving around martial arts. Qian Qiu is more political whereas MDZS has more adventure elements. Both have 'opposites attract' type characters, with powerful martial arts skills
They have a similar main cast. There are also some moments that you can laugh at. It is more action heavy, but Lu, the female character in the cast, almost 1 to 1 looks like Kagura.
